SINGAPORE PUBLIC PASSENGER TRANSPORT SYSTEM
(Unification)


    3. Mr A. P. Rajah asked the Minister for National Development if he will state what steps the Government proposes to take to improve the public transport system in Singapore, and whether early consideration is being given to the unification of the public passenger transport system in Singapore into a single undertaking or other means of improving the public transport System.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, a few days after the new Government was formed, I instructed my Ministry to put up a scheme to improve the bus transport system of Singapore, laying particular stress on the rural areas which are either not adequately served or where there are no buses.

    As a first step, the Omnibus Licensing Authority has recently been reconstituted with honest and capable persons and since then they have been meeting a few times a week to try and improve the mess left over during the past ten year.

    The Government is unable at this stage to make a policy statement regarding the unification of the public passenger transport system in Singapore.

    Mr Rajah: Would the Minister state, in view of the existing conditions of national transport, whether the transport system is adequate to meet the pressing needs of the travelling public?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, the public in Singapore know that during the past ten years, the passenger transport system which was the responsibility of the City Council and in which the Member for Farrer Park played a leading part, has been completely in a mess, with two or three bus lines serving one route and in other places with no bus routes at all.

    We understand the needs of the travelling public as well as the conditions of service of the bus employees. From the first week when the new Government came into being, I was

Column: 656

given the authority to look into the matter and certain steps have been taken to try to remedy the situation. Mr Speaker, one of these steps was the reconstitution of the Omnibus Licensing Authority which replaced the corrupt Vehicles Committee of the City Council in the issuing of licences. We have reconstituted the Omnibus Licensing Authority set up in late 1957 with honest and capable persons and since then they have been meeting a few times a week just to try and remedy a little bit the situation left over in the past ten years.

    Mr Speaker, the new P.A.P. Government has only been formed for four months and the public of Singapore realise that during the past four months we have been doing as best we could to tidy up some of the mess left over and to start everything fresh again.

PEOPLE'S ACTION PARTY
(Details of Employment of Defeated Candidates in Public Services)


    4. Mr A. P. Rajah asked the Minister for National Development how many defeated People's Action Party candidates in the last general election are now or have been employed in the Singapore Improvement Trust, the City Council of Singapore and/or in any department in the Ministry of National Development, and whether he will state their names, the posts held, the manner and date of their appointments and the monthly salaries attached to such posts.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, three of the defeated candidates in the last general elections were members of the City Council staff who had resigned from the City Council to contest the elections. These three are Inche Roslan Bin Hassan who contested on the P.A.P. ticket, Inche Osman bin Gani who contested on the U.M.N.O. ticket, and Mr Chen Ta Ren who contested on the P.A.P. ticket. These three are persons of calibre and integrity. Immediately after the elections. I gave instructions to contact these three persons, asking them to help the new Government in the task of building the country and working for the people. They agreed and they are

Column: 657

now working very hard in the Ministry of National Development. From the time they started, we have given the fullest publicity to their work.

    Inche Roslan and Inche Osman are getting all-in salaries, without the usual civil service benefits, of $400 and $700 a month respectively. They are now working actively on the promotion of Malay welfare, like the work in the Southern Islands. Further, with the Parliamentary Secretary of the Ministry (Inche Yaacob), they interview every day many tens of Malays from all parts of Singapore and help them to solve their problems. The third person, Mr Speaker, Mr Chen Ta Ren has been engaged in the Singapore Improvement Trust. He is now in the flat-letting section, checking through the applications and helping to put an end to the corrupt practices of the past Singapore Improvement Trust. Mr Chen Ta Ren gets an all-in salary of $250 inclusive without the usual civil service benefits.

    Mr Rajah: In view of what the Minister has said, would he agree that, if this system were to be continued, we would fast approach the American spoils system?

    Mr Speaker: It is a matter of opinion.

POLITICAL SECRETARIES
(Disciplinary Action under Government General Orders and Regulations)


    6. Mr A. P. Rajah asked the Minister for Finance to state whether Political Secretaries are subject to Government General Orders and Regulations, and whether disciplinary action will be taken against each and every of the Political Secretaries to the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Labour and Law, the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Finance for having attended and actually participated in the Singapore Traction Company Employees Union's strike meeting held at the Union's premises on 29th September, 1959.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, Personal Secretaries (Political) are political appointments. They hold office at the pleasure of the Government in power. They presumably will be removed from office should at the next election another Party form the Government. There is therefore a basic distinction between the Political Secretary and the career civil servant whose duty it is to serve impartially and to the best of his ability any elected government. The post of Political Secretary does not therefore offer a career and, because of this and the difference in functions and responsibilities from those of the career civil servants, is not subject to the disciplinary provisions of General Orders. The Political Secretary is a member of the political party in the government of the day. As such his public actions and utterances, be they made either in his individual or official capacity, have an important bearing upon the policy of the government. It is therefore his responsibility to clear with his Minister whether his actions or statements are consistent with government and party policy. The control of Political Secretaries is not exercised through normal civil service channels and it would be improper that that should be the case. The control is exercised directly through

Column: 659

the Minister to whom the Political Secretary is attached and through the Minister by the Cabinet. The Member will appreciate that since the system of Political Secretaries is new it will take some time for the relationship between the Minister and his Political Secretary to be defined in detail.

    Mr Rajah: In view of the Minister's statement, could the Minister state whether these five Political Secretaries had clearance from their respective Ministers before they took part in this meeting?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Regarding the instance cited by the Member for Farrer Park, the answer is: Not to my knowledge.

SINGAPORE'S INTERNAL SECURITY
(Statement by the Deputy Prime Minister)


2.44 p.m.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, I have a statement to make on the internal security of Singapore and our relationships with the Federation.

    Sir, this is the first opportunity the P.A.P. Government has had, since assuming office on 5th June, 1959, to make a statement on the question of the security of the State and the Communist challenge. Our basic attitude and philosophy on this question have been stated and restated on innumerable past occasions when the Party was in the Opposition. However, today is the first time we restate the position in some detail after having assumed office. It has not been made earlier because up to the third meeting of the Internal Security Council on the 8th October it was not possible for us to make any statements on this matter. Suffice it to say between the 5th June and 28th August there was correspondence between the Federation Government, the British Government and ourselves to clarify the rights, powers and duties of the Internal Security Council as laid down in Part VII of the Constitution. At the

Column: 660

first meeting of the Internal Security Council, the provisions contained in sections 65 and 66 were considered, and the powers of the Internal Security Council were noted and placed on record in simple language as follows:-

    (i) "The competence of the Singapore Government to formulate and implement the policy affecting internal security is subject to the overriding powers of the Internal Security Council."

    (ii) "In addition to consultation and decisions on questions of policy, the Internal Security Council is competent to make executive decisions for the maintenance of internal security in Singapore, and any such decision which has been communicated to the Singapore Government must be given immediate effect."

    (iii) "The Singapore Government is competent to take executive action on its own authority in matters of internal security. For its part, the Internal Security Council is competent to take decisions in these same matters, and in so far as it does those decisions, by virtue of section 66, paragraph (2), endorse, supplement or override any decisions which the Singapore Government may itself have taken and constitute binding directives with which the subsequent decisions and actions of the Singapore Government must conform."

    (iv) "The Singapore Government should not take any action in any field which would be contrary to policy already agreed by, or decisions already taken by, the Council or would be likely to raise policy issues, or would have repercussions affecting internal security, without prior reference to the Council."

    Sir, the Singapore Government has considered it important that not only the constitutional but also the military and economic power positions of the three Governments participating in the Internal Security Council should be clearly recognised. This power position prevails for this term of office of the Government up till June 1964, and will not be changed just by the United Kingdom Commissioner withdrawing

Column: 661

from the office of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara on the 3rd December, 1959. We have nothing to gain by trying to assume, as the last Government did to its own destruction, powers and responsibilities which were not properly within its province. But at the same time such powers and responsibilities as are within our competence, we shall discharge to the fullest in the interests of our people.

    We agreed to the provisions for an Internal Security Council in June 1957, giving the Federation Government representative a deciding vote on our Security Council, because we recognised that that was better than giving the British Government the decisive say and that, in fact, if we achieved independence we can only do so as a Member State of the Federation, in which case the Federation Government would have a decisive voice in our national policies anyway. Therefore, until independence through merger is achieved, we accept the position of the Federation Government having a deciding vote in the Internal Security Council.

    But apart from the constitutional position, it might be useful to remember also the military and economic positions of the State of Singapore vis-a-vis the British Government and the Federation Government. We have the doubtful honour of having the largest and most important British military base East of Cyprus. The British Government has also a defence pact with the Federation Government. In effect, this means that, to succeed, the Communist challenge for supremacy would have to be strong enough to subdue both the armed might of the Federation and the British, because in military terms a Communist Singapore would not be possible until there is a Communist Malaya. No Communist Party can hope to capture power in Singapore and continue to exist, unless there was already a Communist Government in the Federation.

    This is so simple an analysis that it is not worth further argument or discussion. The fact that the tactics of the Communist Party of Malaya have shifted

Column: 662

their emphasis from armed struggle to penetration and subversion does not alter the validity of the above analysis.

    But the economic power position is not so easily discernible and requires more elaborate explanation. For the last 140 years of British rule, whatever the constitutional niceties of the Colonies in the Straits Settlements, the Federated Malay States and the Unfederated Malay States, Malaya was in fact one economic unit, administered as such by one civil administration manned by the Malayan Civil Service. Now, since independence, we have watched with concern the growing tendency to separate the economy. A fact worth noting is that in both the Federation and Singapore, the same British trading interests have investments. It is obviously in the interest of not only the British but also of Malaya to remain as one economy. But if for political reasons the position cannot be held in the immediate future, then we run grave risks of having the British and the Federation Governments settling such political differences that we may have from time to time through economic instead of political action.

    For this reason, we have considered it important at the outset of our discussions with the Federation to make it unmistakably clear that our hope is to co-operate and not to compete with them, particularly in the economic and social fields. But to avoid any misunderstanding, we have deemed it important that we should not mislead by word or conduct our British overlord, or anyone else, into believing that the Singapore Government can be made into a stooge government. We shall do everything in our power to work for the interests of the people of Malaya. These interests demand the ultimate reunification of the two territories, but co-operation must be on the basis of mutual respect and adherence to certain principles agreed to beforehand.

    Hence it was necessary to clarify the difference in approaches to security problems between a non-Communist Socialist Singapore Government and an anti-Communist Federation Government.

    The Federation Government stressed their different position, particularly as a

Column: 663

result of a militant Communist insurrection. The Singapore Government has stated the following principles by which it would be guided on security problems:-

    (i) The Singapore Government shall not act as a buffer to protect pro-Communist Party forces against the Federation Government. These pro-Communist Party forces, some originally from the Federation and some from Singapore, who are hoping to use Singapore as a refitting base for their struggle in the Federation, must take the consequences of their actions.

    (ii) That it is the duty of the Singapore Government to defend in Singapore the rights of left-wing non-Communist Party forces and to encourage their growth. It is the P.A.P. Government's view that the democratic socialist is the most effective countervailing force in the labour movement in this country, and that our policy is designed to aid the growth of the democratic socialist and not a Communist trade union movement.

    (iii) That while the Singapore Government shall by social, economic and political policies, negate the Communist claim that only the Communists can resolve the social and economic injustices in our society, it would in the meantime prevent the security of the democratic state from being undermined by the Communists.

    Sir, having made our stand on principle, we discussed the question of some 30 odd detainees who were arrested by the previous government in two purges - in October 1956 and September 1957. On the 22nd May, 1959, during the election campaign, I stated that "The P.A.P. would not take office unless former members of the Party who were intimately connected with the Central Executive Committee and who are now in jail are

Column: 664

released." This pledge we have fulfilled. Eight P.A.P. members all those intimately connected with the leadership of the Party were released at our insistence on the 4th June before we assumed office on 5th June. On the 1st June, 1959, immediately after the elections and before forming the Government, my Party's Secretary-General, now the Prime Minister, stated that: "The record of the other detainees will be reviewed and justice done on the merits of each case." At present we do not know the full facts leading to their detention. The P.A.P. does not intend to be or even appear to be the hand-maid of the Communist Party. But we do not intend to soil our hands by putting them in the same gloves once used by the previous Government. That is still our stand.

    We took a lenient line and released four detainees on the 22nd day of June, 1959. Immediately after that, the Internal Security Council joined in the review of all cases. On the 1st day of October, 1959, after prior consideration by the Internal Security Council, four women detainees were released. The work of the Internal Security Council of reviewing the other cases is still proceeding. But let us make it clear to all concerned that whilst we do not wish to be in any way associated with the purge carried out by the previous Government, we shall be less inhibited in taking our own steps to ensure that there is no recurrence of pro-Communist Party activities. Those who embark on such activities do so at their own risk.

    This is also a convenient time for us to say that the Internal Security Council is vigilant and on the watchout for any re-appearance of pro-Communist activists in rural organisations, trade unions, student groups and all the other societies and associations which were formerly exploited for united front purposes. All we wish to say at this stage is that ill-advised activists should learn the lessons of 1956 and 1957. It is our business to look after the welfare and well-being of the people. We have no intention to jeopardise the welfare of the people as a whole for the benefit of a small group whose cause we consider mistaken. Let them ponder on the things we have said

Column: 665

and the many more things that we have left unsaid, and desist from the folly of trying to use Singapore as a refitting base of a struggle for supremacy in the Federation.

BILLS INTRODUCED

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC SECURITY (AMENDMENT) BILL
First Reading


3.01 p.m.


    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Ordinance to amend the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, 1955 (No. 25 of 1955)."

    Bill read the First time.

    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

    The Prime Minister: Now, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Please continue.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, I lay upon the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in respect of the Preservation of Public Security (Amendment) Bill.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Are typed copies available to Members.

    The Prime Minister: Yes.

    Typed copies of the Bill handed in to the Clerk and distributed to hon. Members.
Second Reading


    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, my Party's stand on emergency powers for the Government was stated on the 8th October last year, when the last Assembly debated an amendment to the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance extending its life for another year.

    At the time we made our stand in this House, we envisaged a situation when in October 1959 we would be responsible for the Government, and the

Column: 666

Bill would either lapse or come up for a further extension. It was with circumspection that we set out the principles which guided us, and which led us to the conclusion that as long as there are Emergency laws in the Federation, there will be Emergency laws in Singapore. But for the benefit of Members who were not in this House on the 8th October last year, may I refer them to Volume 3, No. 9 of the Hansard, column 800 for my speech, column 815 for the speech of my colleague, the present Minister for Health, and column 819 for the speech of my colleague, the Member for Tampines.

    May I read a few passages out of the speech I made on that occasion? The beginning of column 803:

    "But, there may be people - I am quite sure that there may be some in important positions not only in Singapore but across the Causeway - who may want to know what the People's Action Party propose to do in the next elections. Is it going to repeat the same anti-Emergency Regulations stand? Is it going to make this an election issue, and then having won the elections seek to abolish the Emergency Regulations and precipitate a crisis? Under normal conditions, Sir, I would tell such nosey and curious people to wait for the proper time in the next few months when we shall be issuing our election manifesto. But it may be that the Federation of Malaya would like to know its position vis a vis Singapore after the next general elections, because the Federation of Malaya has to be represented on our Internal Security Council under the new Constitution. In fact, it is to have the decisive vote. What is to happen to these Emergency laws is a matter of some considerable importance to them, because there are now two political situations; one in the Federation and one in Singapore, both distinct and separate and self-contained with a cordon sanitaire in the Straits of Johore. And they would like to know whether there is going to be a crisis immediately after the general elections, with an emergency meeting of the Internal Security Council summoned by the British to oppose any intended moves to abolish the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance. In such a situation, the Federation may find themselves in the embarrassing position of (1) voting with the British against the Singapore representatives; or (2) voting with the Singapore representatives to abolish the Emergency laws which they in the Federation still consider necessary."

May I then take Members to column 804?

    "As a Party of the "Left", we may not always agree or see eye to eye with a Party

Column: 667

of the "Right", as the Tunku has once called the United Malay Nationalist Organisation. But we can assure them that their views and susceptibilities will be given the most careful consideration by us. We state our stand now on the quest on of the Emergency laws, and it is this: that as long as they are necessary for the maintenance of the security of the Federation, so long will they be necessary for Singapore. Sir, we state this now in the full knowledge and anticipation that there will be political bankrupts and charlatans, those who have, and those who have not ever graced the chairs of this Assembly, who will make promises to abolish them in the next elections. We have met such types before, and we expect to meet them in the next elections. When that time comes, we shall justify out view and our stand, that there will be no abolition of the Emergency laws in Singapore until they have been abolished in the Federation. Those who want the Emergency laws abolished in Singapore should try to help to establish conditions of peace and security in the Federation so that they may no longer be required there."

And again in column 807:

    "But we also wish to say that the use of these Emergency powers depends upon the stand of the persons who are equipped with them, and we stand for an independent, democratic, non-Communist Malaya. Within this democratic system, everyone has the right to compete, to preach his political views, but the competition must be for the purpose of working the system, not of destroying it. These powers will not be allowed to be used against political opponents within the system who compete for the right to work the system. That is fundamental and basic, or the powers will have destroyed the purpose for which they were forged. If in using these powers you, in fact, negate the purpose for which you made them, then you will end up with a situation where force, and more force, will become increasingly necessary."

May I pass on to column 810?

    "Let this also be made known, that our definition of the word "subversion" is probably different from the British definition of that term, and maybe even from the Labour Front definition of that term - "subversion". In our definition "subversion" is any political activity designed to further the aims and interests not of our own people but of foreign powers; and by foreign powers we mean not just Russia and China, but also America and Formosa, and the Western bloc."

And we went on to say on that occasion:

    "We in the People's Action Party would prefer to lose an election rather than win it on false premises and promises."

    Sir, before I proceed to deal with the amendments which this Bill seeks to make, may I remind the Right that our antipathy to local or expatriate agents,

Column: 668

who subordinate the interests of the people of Singapore to foreign power interests, is as strong now as it was when we were the Opposition? Lip service docility will not hide their malevolent intentions to see that the Left Wing Government in Singapore does not succeed to the detriment of the interests of the Right.

    It is really unnecessary for me to elaborate on the reasons for this Bill. But there are some changes about which Members may wish to be informed.

    First, clause 5 of the Bill repeals section 5 of the present Ordinance which provides for an Appeal Tribunal consisting of three judges, and substitutes in its place the original position obtaining under the Emergency laws, that is, an advisory committee.

    In September this year, I had discussions with the present Chief Justice about the functions of the judiciary under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, which is due to lapse later this month. The position is that the judges have been unhappy over their duties under section 6 of the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance and have indicated that they would like to be relieved of their executive responsibilities under that section and act only in an advisory capacity. Sir, this is not something new. In 1955, when the former Chief Minister, Mr David Saul Marshall, had to deceive the people into believing that he had abolished the Emergency Regulations, as he promised to in the last elections, by replacing it with the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, he obtained the consent of the then Chief Justice, Sir Charles Murray-Aynsley, to allow the judges to serve on an executive appeal tribunal. When Sir Charles retired and Sir John Whyatt succeeded him as Chief Justice, protests were made to the then Government about the improper use of the judiciary under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance.

    In September 1958, one month before the Ordinance was due to expire, or come up for extension, the then Chief Minister wrote to the then Acting Chief Justice, Mr Tan Ah Tah, asking him to agree to allow the judges to continue for

Column: 669

one more year under the P.P.S.O. The Acting Chief Justice replied in these terms:
